values: Now that I have given official notice to my landlord, I can make the announcement here, which is that I have undertaken something crazy, which is that...I am building a house. Not me, obviously, with my own two hands, because that would truly be crazy, as I am bad at everything that requires the use of tools, but someone is building a house on my behalf for me to live in. The story goes like this: I have never really liked the townhouse that I live in. I had to rent it because my original landlord of the first apartment I rented here broke the lease on me and left me kind of high-and-dry and so I had to scramble and rent this place sight unseen. It has never been ideal--for one, it's too small for all of my stuff, so I have to step over piles of boxes everywhere--and the list of not-ideal about it has kept growing: There is some kind of leak in the bathrooms that somehow the plumber thinks is the result of me throwing water around pell-mell (not a thing that I do). The stove doesn't actually work properly. The hot water heater doesn't actually work properly. One day sparks flew out of the electrical outlet in the bathroom and caught my hair dryer on fire while I was using it. Et cetera. I am actually an INCREDIBLY picky person, as anyone who knows me knows well, and this house suits none of my pickiness. I don't like how the windows don't have screens so I can't open them (I like fresh air). I don't like how it not only doesn't have a microwave, it also doesn't have room for one. I don't like how the gas fireplace is an open flame. I don't like how the smoke alarm in the kitchen is so sensitive that to cook I have to open up all the doors (because again, no screens), even when it's below freezing outside. I don't like how the heat doesn't work right, so it's always freezing downstairs and a sauna upstairs. Et cetera. I am not a huge fan of the neighborhood I'm in. Behind my house is a bunch of fratboys whose yard is always so gross. Sometimes I try to detail the things they have in their yard. My favorite is the ladder they have for an above-ground swimming pool...which they don't have. And sometimes they just randomly light couches on fire in the backyard. Seems safe. And my little outdoor area is RIGHT up against their yard, so that if they're out there, I can't be outside because it's awkward (probably only in my head. But still). I'm on a hill, which I don't like because I can't see if cars are coming up the hill and so I freak out every time I leave the driveway. I'm across from a cemetery, which also freaks me out and attracts deer who like to try to kill themselves in front of my car. There are no sidewalks around my house, which cuts down on walks, which I would really like to take. Et cetera. And I knew all this about this place but in my head I was like, "This is temporary, this is all temporary, it's good enough." And then one day I woke up and I'd been here three years and I was looking at a fourth and I was like, "Why am I living my life like this?" There's a lot about my life I can't change, so I therefore try to be good about the things I can change. I don't like where I live in a larger sense and have little control over that, but I can at least try to like my little piece of where I live. Oh! And I haven't even gotten into the shenanigans with the trash in this neighborhood! Right after I moved in, somebody stole my trash can. I was bewildered, like, what did this mean? I know they stole mine, because they left one behind in its wake, and it was stained with, like, bleach or something, in a way mine hadn't been, and it had all garbage in it that was not mine. So I spent a little while being like, "...Has someone killed someone and left the body here in their trash can and taken my trash can instead?" Not really knowing what to do (like, should I have called the police? That seemed like an overreaction???), I put the trash can out as usual. That particular trash day, I noticed that someone had put a trash can out that looked like mine, so I decided that maybe their taking of mine and leaving of theirs was some kind of weird mistake? Or something? Whatever, I took my non-stained trash can back and spray painted my address on it to deter such a thing happening again, because I don't want other people's garbage in my trash. Too bad that doesn't deter the people in my neighborhood. For some reason, they are OBSESSED with throwing their trash in my trash can. WHAT IS UP WITH THIS? My trash can was up the side of my house, so they had to walk up my driveway to the back of my house to do this and I'm annoyed by this. I DON'T WANT OTHER PEOPLE'S TRASH IN MY TRASH CAN. I DON'T WANT OTHER PEOPLE AT THE END OF MY DRIVEWAY, WHERE IT'S DARK, LURKING AROUND NEAR MY TRASH CAN. I think that's weird. Am I weird to think that's weird? So then I took to hiding my trash can behind my fence, around the corner of my house, all the way in the back, and that does seem to deter people, thankfully. Trash days here are Monday and Thursday mornings. One Wednesday evening, I put out my trash can. On Thursday evening when I got home from work I went to retrieve it and it was gone. And there wasn't even a sketchy one left in its place. And I kind of decided that I'd had enough of the trash shenanigans and snapped a little bit and e-mailed the city to tell them my trash can had been stolen. And here's where the story gets HILARIOUS. Because it turns out the city had confiscated my trash can! They thought it was "abandoned"! I was like, "...Wasn't yesterday a trash day in my neighborhood? I had the trash can out because it was trash day, not because I was abandoning it." And the city was like, "Yeah, our bad, sorry about that, we'll bring it back to you." And then--GUYS, THIS IS A THING THAT REALLY HAPPENED--they sent me an e-mail with a photograph attached and ASKED ME TO PICK MY TRASH CAN OUT OF A LINEUP OF TRASH CANS THEY HAD CONFISCATED. THIS WAS A THING THEY ASKED ME TO DO WITH A STRAIGHT FACE. I got this e-mail while I was sitting in the coffee shop working and I started laughing so uncontrollably that I think I alarmed people but REALLY. *REALLY.* I ended up being able to pick it out of the line-up because of the fact that I'd helpfully spray painted my address on it. So, anyway, the trash can stuff wasn't the final straw but I am hoping my new neighborhood is less crazy about the trash stuff. At first I thought I'd just rent a nicer, slightly bigger place, but the rental market here is OUT OF CONTROL. The prices were making me laugh hysterically. I was like, "I think I could buy a house and pay less money per month than these people want." And it turns out: Yeah. I could. So there's this development going up in a part of town I really like and I walked through it and really liked it. You can pick your own floorplan from a list and it's kind of a New-Orleans-y neighborhood with gas lamps all over the place and the neighborhood has sidewalks! I would have a gas kitchen!!!!! I haven't had a gas kitchen in SO MANY YEARS. Just that alone made me want to buy the place. So I ran all the numbers and the mortgage payment would be many hundreds of dollars less than if I kept renting and I was like, "I guess. Might as well." I'm not going into it thinking I'm going to make a bunch of money off of this house, because I know real estate and in my experience, that's not how it works. I'm going into it, though, thinking that it would be nice to have something to look forward to about this place. And, in that respect, it really has worked. I think about this house and I'm *excited.* Like, I really want to live in it. And that's nice. And I've been astonished by how much fun it's been to make the house *mine.* I thought I'd be completely overwhelmed but it turns out when I sat down and thought about it seriously, I knew exactly what I wanted in the house. The woman who helped me pick the finishes said she was really impressed with how well I knew my own style, and I realized that I have spent literally years thinking about this. I have opinions on almost everything house-related. And what I don't have opinions on isn't because I haven't thought about it but because I have thought about it and genuinely don't care. So I feel like all that HGTV-watching and NBT-writing and Architectural-Digest-reading has really paid off for me. When I had to pick paint colors, the woman was like, "So, let me get swatches," and I said, "No, I want Benjamin Moore Cloud White on every wall and ceiling in this house," and she was like, "...Wow. You *do* know what you want." And this *is* the kind of thing I don't think I would have ever been able to afford up north, so it's nice to finally feel like there's a positive to being down here, and that's that I've gotten to have this experience of designing my own house. Which *has* been interesting to do down here. I'm glad I've lived in the South for a while before starting this so I can confidently assert the things that would go without saying up north but that I know are weird down here. Like, it turns out the most expensive thing in my house is my desire for the gas fireplace to be glassed in. I had never seen open-flame gas fireplaces until I moved down here and it would never have occurred to me to check to make sure it would be glassed in until I'd lived here, so I'm glad I checked. The woman was completely bewildered by my insistence on the glass. But, on the flipside, she was completely bewildered that I don't mind having the garbage disposal operated from a switch on the wall. She said that everybody down here pays extra to have a button put on their counter, which to me just seems weird and I don't want another thing on my counter that I have to avoid. But I saved myself some money there, I guess! So yeah, that's my crazy news. The house is supposed to be done in six months, which will be *just* in time for the next school year to start. We're cutting it close, so I'm hoping there are no weather delays. I've only got lighting left to pick out. Actually, not true, I looked through literally thousands of lights and picked out my lighting and went to the lighting place (open M-F, 9-5, so that's super-convenient when you're working, as you can imagine) and they were like, "Are you sure? Most people change their minds. Come back later." Grr. I AM SURE. I will go back again and *insist* this time on what I want. I find I'm pretty good if I don't let people convince me that my taste is something different. This whole thing has been a lesson in being able to assert that I know what I like in the face of dubiousness otherwise. But I think the house is going to be very, very ME when it is done, and that might make it complicated to resell, but for now, it's been fun to spin out what that is. :-)

I went to “Hamilton” last night, and I know lots of people asked me to share what I thought afterward, and at the time I was like, “Sure!” but I ended up having a very different “Hamilton” experience than I had thought I would, so this turned into a story not really about “Hamilton” in which I am annoying and self-pitying and you should just skip to the bullet points.

I mean, I saw “Hamilton,” so it wasn’t like some really horrible thing happened. And it was really good. But Lin-Manuel Miranda was sick yesterday, so we had an understudy, and we also had a standby for Eliza (I learned yesterday the difference between understudies and standbys, it was all very informative), and, I mean, they were fine, they were hired by the hottest show on Broadway, it wasn’t like I didn’t think they would be fine.

But I would be lying if I didn’t say that it wasn’t an enormous disappointment to me and the primary memory I have of my “Hamilton” experience. Which is sad and also unfair, because these things happen, and it’s silly for me to not be focused on all of the really awesome part of “Hamilton,” which *were* really awesome, and I know I was lucky to just be in the room at all, etc., etc., but I can’t help it: I was sad yesterday and I’m sad today. My most visceral “Hamilton” memory turns out mainly to have been that I stood in the line for the ladies’ room and watched the rumor about LMM spread through the rest of the line. Which was really quite something to see. It was like the part in “Rudolph” when all the elves are like “Hermey doesn’t like to make toys!” and it goes spreading through the whole line of elves. And mostly when people asked me today how “Hamilton” was, I remembered the way I felt in that moment. Which was not good. And I was mad at myself for feeling not good, so then I was both sad and irritated with myself. And I never really recovered from it for the rest of the play. Like, I just started the play in a not-good headspace and I spent the entire first few songs giving myself a pep talk, like, “This is good! This is great! You’re having a good time! Look how amazing it is! You’ve been looking forward to this for so long! Enjoy it!”

But that was exactly the issue: I’d been looking forward to it for a long time. I was so excited for it. I actually bought my ticket many months ago, and it was a huge decision for me. It wasn’t cheap, as you can imagine, and it wasn’t easy, as you can also imagine, and I justified it to myself and to all my friends and family as being like, “But if I wait and see it at a different time, I won’t get this particular original cast experience, and that’s what I want.”

I was prepared for lots of things to go wrong. I was, in fact, even prepared for the possibility that the original cast would start to leave by the time I got there. I had braced myself for it. But that didn’t happen. Then I was worried that there would be an issue with the ticket, which didn’t come to pass. And I was also worried about the seat itself, because after all of the time and expense of acquiring the ticket, I realized it was partial view, and I was okay with that because at least it got me in the room where it happened and it would be okay.

Which is why I say this was all about managed expectations and how poorly I managed mine. Because the seat? Was AMAZING. Guys, seriously, if you have the chance to buy a partial view seat and you’re questioning it, I wouldn’t. Yeah, there were parts of the stage I couldn’t see, but I was in the fifth row. And I had spent literally hundreds of dollars less than for full-view seats. I thought it was totally worth it. BUT I had managed my expectations on that. I had braced myself for it to be terrible, so I was super-impressed when it was better than terrible.

But the understudy possibility had, for some reason, not occurred to me. I don’t know why. I mean, it totally should have. I have no idea why I just didn’t consider the possibility that I wouldn’t see all of the main cast. I really, really should have, but I didn’t, so it just absolutely caught me by surprise when it happened. Like, I didn’t have time to brace myself, and then I didn’t have time to recover, and it just was kind of whatever after that. Was it good? Yes. Of course it was good. It’s a good play. It’s an incredible play. But it wasn’t the “Hamilton” experience I’d wanted. I know I sound whiney and annoying and entitled. Trust me, I have been yelling at myself for not being able to get my enthusiastic energy up since last night. It was awesome. It was very good. I had a good time.

But if you’re going to see “Hamilton,” I genuinely hope your experience blows mine out of the water.

And, if you’re not going to see “Hamilton,” the good news is that I think you’re going to be absolutely fine if you don’t get to see it for a long time, with a traveling cast, etc. It’s a good play. It’ll hold up fine no matter who’s playing the roles. And, in fact, I think you will be fine if you never get to see “Hamilton.” I mean, I’m glad I saw it, but it’s really true that you have the entire play in the soundtrack.

So, ANYWAY, I know you’re all waiting for my *actual impressions of the play,* which are below, with the obvious caveat that I didn’t see LMM or Phillippa Soo, so obvs I can’t speak to what the play is like with them:

–The choreography of the play is pretty amazing. The dancers are incredible.

–My favorite song live was actually “The Reynolds Pamphlet.” That song is AMAZING live. There was so much more going on than I realized from the soundtrack. My second-favorite was “Cabinet Battle Number One.” That was super-fun, and much funnier than I thought from the soundtrack.

–Everyone working at the Richard Rodgers Theater is INCREDIBLY nice. I couldn’t get over it. They were so smiling and cheerful, even though it was basically a zoo. Kudos to them. They were wonderful.

–Thanks to @marsdaydream for the tip that you get a souvenir glass when you order a drink! I love my souvenir glass!

–The biggest ovation of the night was after “The Room Where It Happens.”

–The play is called “Hamilton” but it’s definitely Burr’s story. The audience connection is entirely with Burr. Leslie Odom, Jr., breaks the fourth wall a lot and is constantly rolling his eyes, and the disbelieving stare he uses on Hamilton is hilarious. He’s fantastic in the role. I don’t know if this was just because I saw the understudy or what, but I was totally on Burr’s side. (I am not usually that way on the soundtrack, so I definitely found Burr’s story more compelling live.)

–Least favorite thing to discover from watching it live: They apparently don’t actually sing the “1776″ reference. Or maybe just the understudy doesn’t? But that was a sadface.

–Favorite thing to discover from watching it live: King George puts air quotes around “country” on “I Know Him”: “There’s no one else in their ‘country’ who looms quite as large.” Seriously, King George was the best. See below:

–I had heard that Jonathan Groff was the scene-stealer in the show but nothing prepared for how much he actually is. He was amazing. He’s not in it a bunch obvs but he dominates what he’s in. He’s great.

–Christopher Jackson’s Washington is fantastic. Better live for me than on the soundtrack. Very charismatic.

–Daveed Diggs is so excellent. When all the news about the understudies was circulating, I was like, “Ugh, at *least* let me get to see Daveed Diggs,” so that made me really happy. (See? All about managing expectations! Once I was told the understudy news, I was seriously relieved by every single person I actually got to see. I felt so, so lucky.) I love his Jefferson. I want there to be a double billing of “Hamilton” and “1776″ and Diggs plays Jefferson in both. I think that would be amazing. Again, don’t know if this was because I saw the understudy performance or what, but I actually was on Jefferson’s side live much more than on the soundtrack. Diggs is just super-compelling.

–I saw Jon Rua as Hamilton. He struck me as being much more puppyish than I had anticipated the part to be. I eavesdropped on the person behind me who had seen the show multiple times and who said Rua’s take was “more boyish.” I think that did affect the fact that I wasn’t overly fond of Hamilton. I felt like Burr and Jefferson frankly just wanted him to grow up a little bit, and I sympathized with them. Also, he smiled almost constantly, which made Burr’s “smile more” advice feel sarcastic. This might be how it always is? I don’t know, but I had never read it that way before, and it was interesting to have that spin put on it.

So that’s that! I feel like I should have something more interesting to say, but honestly it was just kind of an exhaustingly emotional ordeal. Ah, the highs and lows of fandom! I am really looking forward (WITH VERY CAREFULLY MANAGED EXPECTATIONS, OF COURSE) to the possibility of a film, because I really would like to see LMM do the role.

--OMG, you guys, OMGGGGGGGGGGGGG. Was that amaaaaazing? Because, let’s face it, the best part of HLV is the Sherlock’s mind palace scene, and somehow they found a way to make that last for 90 minutes. --I have this theory, and that theory is that Moffat is actually in the Inception fandom, and that’s why Doctor Who and now Sherlock are so frequently just Inception crossovers. Like, I’ve written the Limbo scene where Moriarty tries to taunt Sherlock to die with him. John saves Sherlock in my Limbo scene, too. (Arthur, by the way, absolutely does not approve of how many layers down Sherlock was. It’s why his dream got so unstable. He needed some sedative in the Somnacin.) --So. Mary in Sherlock’s head is a fascinating little creature, isn’t she? In Sherlock’s head, Mary is all-knowing and constantly reminding him of how stupid he is. If you needed confirmation that it really haunts Sherlock that he missed the fact that John Watson’s wife was an assassin until she was pointing a gun at him, well, I think this was it. In Sherlock’s head, Mary asks when it occurred to Sherlock that she was more than she seemed and Sherlock admits ruefully, “Only now, I’m afraid.” Yeah, we’ve seen this scene before. It ended in Sherlock flatlining on an operating table. Here, Mary smiles sweetly and taunts, “Must be difficult, being the slow little brother.”   Sherlock is the slow little brother, it’s true, and he knows it, but Sherlock has one person smarter than Mycroft in this episode, and that’s Mary. Mary is constantly one-upping Mycroft. That’s how much credit Sherlock gives to Mary. He has her on this ridiculous pedestal. Forget Irene Adler (well done, John, being creepy in your quest to uncover your rival for Sherlock’s affections); to this Sherlock Holmes, Mary Watson is The Woman. He even gives her the responsibility of saving all of England.   And it was also striking to me how much time and energy Sherlock devotes in his head to saving the Watson marriage. He spotlights again and again in his head how much tension there is in the marriage: they barely see each other, they barely have a civil conversation with each other, etc. The only reason they stop arguing is he because he forces them to stop. This was Sherlock’s role throughout S3, basically: Sherlock holds the Watson relationship together through sheer force of will. He thinks Mary is of all-consuming importance to John (why wouldn’t he think that? He thinks Mary is the cleverest being of them all, and John Watson likes clever and dangerous people), so he ties himself up in knots to give John Mary. He shrugs off his own murder in the service of the Watson marriage. He gives up his own life for their marriage, multiple times. Sherlock just never stops trying to save the Watson marriage. In his head, he finally gets them there by giving Mary an epic heroic position of Super Sekrit Mycroft Spy who magically solves the entire mystery with minimal explanation. Mary, in Sherlock’s head, is the superhero. And, of course, forcing John to acknowledge the superheroics of his wife is what pushes John back to her. Why would John want Sherlock Holmes when he can have the extraordinary Mary Watson?   “Are you even in a fit state?” “For Mary, of course. Never doubt that, Watson. Never that.” Because she is Mary. And Sherlock has to make sure that John never doubts that Sherlock wants the best for Mary. Sherlock can’t have John thinking that he is not dedicated to the well-being of the Watson marriage. Sherlock thinks that would drive John away, I think. --It's official now, everyone: Sherlock ships Mycroft and Lestrade: “I’ll put them in a graveyard. Lestrade will engage in manual labor and roll up his sleeves. There will be a corpse with worms. WHAT COULD BE MORE ROMANTIC???” We Mystraders always thought that those two bonded over their shared worry over Sherlock, and there it was explicitly on the screen. “Don’t mind me, guys! Go ahead and make out! I’m going to go dig frantically in the dirt over here and not pay attention! Maybe I’ll pull a skeleton over me for added privacy!” --Sherlock needed to be high to get through saying good-bye to John. Sherlock needed to be high to get through saying good-bye to John. SHERLOCK NEEDED TO BE HIGH TO GET THROUGH SAYING GOOD-BYE TO JOHN. --That scene between Mycroft and John at the end. When Mycroft’s kind of like, “John. Dude. Do you think you could do a better job of taking care of my bother than you have so far?” We are such a long way from that first conversation in that darkened warehouse, and, from Mycroft’s perspective, I don’t think we’ve traveled entirely in the right direction. “He could be the making of my brother or make him worse than ever,” Mycroft said in the very first episode, and I’ve always kind of shrugged that line off. I thought Mycroft meant John might make Sherlock more insufferable, but now I think Mycroft saw this coming: John can make Sherlock’s self-destructive self-loathing worse than ever, and right now Mycroft is basically begging John to notice that. --Stanford’s tie, you guys. NEVER CHANGE, STANFORD. OWN THAT TIE IN EVERY ERA. --I can’t even start with the number of multi-layered references, to ACD canon and BBC canon and then fanon on top of everything else. There were so many layers of interwoven narrative. “Is it silly enough for you? Mad enough? Gothic enough?” The only piece of writing more meta than “Next Big Thing” is “The Abominable Bride.” --The flashbacks at the beginning were so interesting. Like, they don’t do anything about Sherlock being shot. Are we just going to ignore that for the rest of time? I am genuinely worried we’re just going to ignore that for the rest of time. I’m trying not to let it worry me. But yes. (They also don’t do anything with Baskerville or The Blind Banker, either, confirming that those episodes are just so pointless, ha.) --Sherlock says he is reading John’s blog because he’s cleverer through John’s eyes. And Sherlock’s first-level mind palace is entirely through John’s eyes. It starts with John’s story, it’s narrated by John, it’s about how John sees him. Everyone’s constantly talking about the stories John tells, about the entanglement of the fictional Sherlock with the real Sherlock, because Sherlock works so hard in his head to be the Sherlock John sees. John wants Sherlock held to a higher standard, and Sherlock wants to achieve that so desperately. (Of course, he can only really hold onto this idea in the first level.)   But Sherlock’s head is such an astonishing place because it betrays with certainty that, for all of his bluster, he actually thinks lots of people are cleverer than he is. Mary certainly is, and Mycroft, and even John in Sherlock’s head is “pretty damn smart.” “You’re the expert,” Sherlock allows to John, and it might be in limited areas, but they’re areas that count pretty heavily. Especially when your whole life is a story you’re trying to tell to others so they don’t notice the true you. Being an expert storyteller comes in handy with that. --From Sherlock’s beating the corpse we can discern: Sherlock has a lot of aggression to get out.   From John’s little half-smile at Sherlock beating the corpse we can discern: John’s totally a-okay with that, yup. --If I got started on all the little moments I loved, I’d never stop:   the fantastic first scene with Mrs. Hudson,   “There’s a woman in my sitting room. Was that intentional?”,   the whole twins dialogue,   Sherlock’s delight over his “death us do part” joke,   the sign language bit,   the way Sherlock says “yes” to Moriarty’s question about dust being skin cells, like, “obviously, Moriarty, that’s Creepy Science 101,”   “Speaking as a criminal mastermind, we don’t really have gongs. Or special outfits.”,   the way Moriarty delivers that “The Napoleon of Crime” line. --In every episode of Sherlock, there must be at least one John Watson Likes the Ladies scene. Behold, John knows Molly is a female. Why? Because John Watson knows ladies, k? --Lestrade and Mrs. Hudson are the cutest. I want at least one scene with just them, forever. --I love John Watson the writer. We don’t get as much of him in modern canon. I loved how much depended on John Watson being a storyteller here. --Why does Sherlock seem so upset about John’s dancing lessons? Is it because he didn’t get to give John the dancing lessons in 1895? --In Sherlock’s head, Mycroft is enormous in stature (literally) and involved in everything but cheerfully willing to die and go away at a fixed point in time in the very near future. It’s like Sherlock’s head can’t actually bear to be rid of Mycroft entirely, but soothes itself by thinking, “You only have to put up with him for a little while longer.” Ah, the Sherlock/Mycroft relationship. --Note how much the Holmeses deny their emotions in Sherlock’s head. They both seem delighted to pretend they don’t have hearts, and Sherlock is constantly denying that he feels any emotions at all, even in the face of John’s conviction otherwise. This contrasts so beautifully with how over-the-top emotional both of them are in the modern day scenes. Sherlock is reading the blog of the day he met John what the hell Sherlock and Mycroft looks about ready to weep, a far cry from the Mycroft we usually see, sincere and broken and sweet. These Holmeses try so hard to be so stiff-upper-lip in their heads, because they are such emotional disasters, it’s a mess. --Yeah, Mycroft, a lot of this is your fault because I don’t understand why you ever had Sherlock in prison in the first place. And why don’t you get him a pardon? WHAT ARE YOU DOING, MYCROFT? WHY DO YOU REMAIN SUCH A CONFUSING PART OF HLV? But that bit where Mycroft says, “What do you think of MI-5 security?” and Mary says, “I think it would be a good idea”? The look Mycroft gives Mary? I’m like, “That’s right, Mycroft, she killed your beloved little brother who you’ve gone to a lot of trouble to keep alive and now she’s insulting your security. TAKE HER DOWN, MYCROFT.” --You know, whenever Sherlock gets really excited and happy about something, that’s the moment when people tell him to dial it down a notch. No wonder Sherlock has learned to pretend not to have emotions. --“Death. DEATH. Nothing, drop it, nothing, hahaha, lovely weather we’re having.” Eustace Carmichael, you’re my ridiculous favorite right there. --Okay. So. The discussion they have while on their ghost stakeout. I read that as: Sherlock is so frustrated by exactly how much John doesn’t understand Sherlock’s feelings for him. He wants John to be obsessed with his sex life but can’t even imagine how that would go. Instead, John asks him annoying, pointless questions he wishes would stop, because he can’t imagine John asking him the questions he wants asked (“Are you in love with me? Would you like to spend the rest of our lives together?”). (Incidentally, this was also a point in KtCR, that Sherlock couldn’t imagine John saying he loved him, not even in his wildest dreams. It’s true in this episode, too. Sherlock can’t quite get himself there.)   So Sherlock wants to have a super-intimate conversation with John, but he can’t imagine what that John would be like. For Sherlock, the central trait of John is that he doesn’t get how Sherlock feels. Sherlock creates for himself a John who is deeply involved in Sherlock’s love life, but it manifests itself in weird invasions of privacy to spy on Sherlock instead of anything more traditionally romantic, because Sherlock can’t see how anything else would go.   With the added complication, of course, that it’s Victorian London and Sherlock is, I think, obviously gay. The whole time John was questioning him, I was like, “John Watson, he’s a homosexual. Stop pestering him.” But then I guess that’s why John asks what “made” Sherlock this way. Like, is he trying to “cure” Sherlock? Does Sherlock think John wants to “cure” him? It all fits in very nicely with the very last scene about Sherlock being “a man out of his time.” A gay man in London was definitely out of his time, but I don’t think Sherlock feels comfortable in modern times, either. Sherlock can’t imagine the world where he just is. --Moriarty mentions rolling around in Sherlock’s bed. Everything about Sherlock’s conversation with Moriarty is sexually charged, because Sherlock can’t get that level of flirtation from John. --This is me whenever Mary talks: Shut up.   “You’re not making any sense, Sherlock.” Me: Shut up.   “He didn’t seem high.” Me: Shut up.   And, like, why is Mary snooping through Sherlock’s phone? Put his phone down, Mary. Ugh. --It was good to see Janine again. Is Sherlock’s head trying to deal with all of the women he’s wronged? --That scene in the graveyard, before the Mystrade date. In that scene, John abandons Sherlock (to go off with Mary). John yells at him that too many people indulge Sherlock. It’s what Sherlock thinks he needs to hear, of course. Mycroft and Lestrade stay behind to help Sherlock because I think Sherlock thinks they’re the people who indulge him too much. Mycroft and Lestrade are the people who love him no matter what, who will be there for him always, and he knows that. He’s less certain about John, though. After all, John has The Great Mary, and John wants Sherlock to hold himself to a higher standard. Sherlock can disappoint John. He knows that. He has in the past.   Which makes it such an incredibly sweet triumph that, the next layer down, in the confrontation with Moriarty, John comes back. John doesn’t leave him alone and abandoned. John comes back and says that Sherlock is never alone. Sherlock gets to hear it, and Sherlock finds his way back to the world. It’s always John Watson who gives Sherlock a reason to come back. You get the feeling Mycroft knows that, when he asks John to take care of Sherlock. Mycroft can stand by and hold a torch all he wants while Sherlock digs himself into huge holes, but it’s John Watson who really keeps Sherlock alive, and Mycroft needs him to understand that.   And Moriarty, of course, suggests John and Sherlock elope. It’s the closest Sherlock gets in his own head to an acknowledgment of what the relationship between him and John really is, the closest he’ll let himself get to it, and I think, for him, it’s enough that he got to have that moment. It’s possibly more than he thought he’d ever have, even in his own head. YOU KILL ME, SHERLOCK HOLMES. --The actual best part of this episode is when Sherlock’s hair and coat come back.

First let me start by saying that the most important thing about my writing year is that my AO3 account got fixed. It had been getting progressively slower and slower, until by the end it was completely unuseable. AO3 worked fine for me if I wasn’t logged in, but if I was logged in, it refused to load. It didn’t matter which browser I used, which computer I used, which network I was on. The problem, it was clear, was with my account. And the lovely tech wizards figured it out for me. It turns out that you can’t have 60,000 messages in your AO3 inbox. Who knew??? I never use my AO3 inbox, so I literally had never looked at the thing, and apparently it can slow down your entire AO3 experience. So here’s my PSA: If you, like me, don’t use your AO3 inbox, if you having a sub-optimal AO3 experience, go in and delete your messages. It’s worked like a charm since they did that. THANKS, AO3 TECH SUPPORT!

And, because my AO3 got fixed, now I can give you my stats as found on my AO3 dashboard (I never realized that was there! I clearly fail at optimal use of AO3).

According to AO3 I wrote, um, 707,778 words this year. YOU GUYS. That’s actually not entirely accurate, because I probably posted things I wrote last year, just like I have things written now that I haven’t posted yet, but I feel like most of those words, as we know, belonged to NBT.

January: When the year started, I was in the middle of posting “Keep the Car Running,”my Sherlock/Inception crossover. That fic was actually entirely written when I started posting it. I had finished it in August 2014, shortly before I started posting it in September 2014. My plan was supposed to be to write KtCR Part II while I was posting KtCR. Things didn’t work out that way. As we shall see. At any rate, I kept posting KtCR original flavor until April.

The very first fic I posted in 2015, though, was the appropriately named “Happy New Year,”a Lucky fic.

Also this month I posted “Fixer-Upper,” the first HGTV verse fic. I wrote it in one day, I’m pretty sure, and posted it as I was writing it, a tradition I kept up for NBT (see below), although not just for one day.

February: My parents had to cancel their third consecutive trip out to see me. Sad, I started writing “Next Big Thing.” And it ate up my life. And broke my AO3. And introduced me to the most amazing people. And those amazing people commented and commented and commented. And wrote so many amazing spin-off fics and made so much amazing art and gah, I can’t even. I am so proud of and delighted by and in love with this silly, happy, gigantic tangle of fluffy banter and all of its progeny and repercussions. I wrote NBT as I posted it, and I was writing and posting NBT until July, and that is the reason why KtCR Part II wasn’t done when it was time to start posting it. I kept saying, “Oh, I’ll finish up NBT quickly and get back to KtCR Part II,” and it just kept not happening.

Also this month I took part in the Come at Once challenge and wrote “Don’t Say I Didn’t Warn You.”

April: I finished posting KtCR. I then posted “Working Together,” a quick ficlet in the KtCRverse that I’d actually written in September 2014, when I had finished writing KtCR.

May: I posted “what r u wearing,” another quick KtCR ficlet that I’d written in September 2014.

I also posted “School,” a sweet little Oliver ficlet about, well, school.

June: I started posting KtCR, Part II. It wasn’t done. I had about eight chapters written. “Surely,” I thought, “NBT has to be almost done now.” NBT took another month, and then I went away for a trip in August, and then had to move back down to work, and long story short, for the final few chapters of KtCR, Part II, I was furiously writing them on Sunday and posting them on Wednesday. Not actually my preferred way to write something as heavily plotty as KtCR, Part II was. That fic gave me absolute fits and made me decide I am never tackling HLV again. It’s just too much of a mental mess for me. I think that’s probably it for me and Mary.

As a gift for a friend who prompted me with it, I wrote and posted “Holmes Family Feud.” And then, because I had long wanted to write the same prompt in two different fandoms, I wrote an Inception version, “The Top Survey Responses for ‘Terrible Ideas.’”

July: I finally finished posting NBT. It ends with a romantic speech that stressed me out so much. And then a Willy Wonka quote. Which probably tells you everything you need to know about NBT.

August: I posted a Fixer-Upper DVD Commentary and started posting an NBT DVD Commentary. I haven’t added to it in a few weeks, but it’s not abandoned. I just have to wait until I have more time. The holidays are busy.

For Inceptiversary, I helped out with a “Fandom Tutorials, Guides & Tips.”

September: I almost forgot that I posted “Changing the Wallpaper” this month! A quick little NBT ficlet that I wrote and posted quickly one night after being inspired by photographs of Tom Hardy (as happens).

There was also a crazy Twitter collaboration, “The Many Faces of Eames.”

October: I had actually written “Pumpkin Spice Latte” in the fall of 2014. I was posting KtCR at the time and about to embark on posting “Lucky,” so I saved PSL until this fall (I felt like it had to show up during pumpkin spice season). I had been hoping to be done with KtCR, Part II, but I decided I couldn’t wait. I was remiss in writing up a Halloween fic, so I used this one instead.

This was all Inception Reverse Bang month, and I was blessed with some fabulous artwork. I posted “Connoisseur of Aquariums” and “The Way Out.”

November: I finished posting (and writing) KtCR, Part II. Just in time for the special! (I wanted to be done with the story by the time the special aired.)

I also went kind of crazy on Twitter with other awesome peeps over the idea of “An ‘Are You the One?’ Inception AU. Of Sorts.”

December: I finished posting PSL.

I started writing and posting “Pining for You,” my Hallmark Christmas movie fic for the Inception fandom, about half of which was written while I was stranded in an airport for holiday travel.

I also started posting “Epilogue: Arthur and Eames,” a Chanukah fic in the KtCRverse that I wrote ages ago. There will be a matching Johnlock epilogue. I know exactly what happens in it, I just have to, ahem, write it.

Favorite Fic: “Next Big Thing.” Everything about the creative process of NBT was so joyous, and I love that it’s so long and was written so quickly that I can re-read it and be endlessly surprised myself because I don’t remember writing so much of it. And I like that I think it’s a genuinely funny fic. And I like everyone in this bar. :-)

Hardest Fic: “Keep the Car Running, Part II.” This fic was an epic struggle. Every time I thought I closed one plot hole, another one sprang up somewhere else. Character motivation kept being all over the place and I had no idea how the fic was going to end until I wrote the last chapter; I just could not decide. I am glad to be done with it. Let me tell you, writing the scene where Mary shoots Sherlock was actually so upsetting that I procrastinated it forever and then, once it was done, I walked away from the fic so I could recover. It’s no coincidence at all that the fic I kept walking away to was NBT, which was so frothy and angst-free that it basically floats off the page.

Filthiest Fic: Do I write filthy fics? Does the NBT shepherd fanfic Arthur writes count? Actually, I think the club scene in NBT might be my favorite filthy-ish scene I wrote this year.

Do you plan to take prompts in 2016? I don’t know, guys. I generally have a tendency to burn myself out with overcommitments fanfic-wise, and this has been a crazy committed year. There weren’t exactly prompts, there were just a lot of different ‘verses that needed my attention and that I had posting schedules for. It just got a little crazy. I probably will scale back a little bit this year. And make sure (once the KtCR Johnlock epilogue is over) that I only post after I’m done writing. Because that’s how I get myself overcommitted, is having WIPs that are actually IP and not just fake IP. I NEED TO STOP POSTING ARTHUR/EAMES FICS RIGHT AWAY. IT’S NOT GOOD.

What was the best thing about 2015? The NBT comment party.

What was the worst thing about 2015? AO3 giving me so much trouble. But then that thankfully got resolved. KtCR, Part II, giving me so much trouble. Which has been somewhat resolved. HLV giving me so much trouble. Who knows if that’s going to be resolved? Only Mofftiss knows that.

Any last thoughts for 2015? It was kind of a crazy year writing-wise, but I wrote a lot of things entirely because I wanted to write them, and I think that’s the best reason in the world to write something. I wrote some original stuff this year, too, that I didn’t document in the above, but it was nice to have the fic on the side and to have the fic be as self-indulgent as my fic generally was this year. And it was nice to have all of you along for the ride.

Best Movie I Saw This Year: “Mad Max: Fury Road.” I did not expect to be impressed by this movie. I was very impressed by this movie. Many words have been written about amazing this movie is, so I don’t really need to write any more. All I have to say is: Thanks, Tom Hardy, for being in this movie, so that I felt compelled to go and see it, and therefore got to experience it. Movie That Surprised Me the Most This Year: “The Night Before.” I was, on the whole, actually pretty bad about stalking my various boyfriends in their movies this year. But I did go see “The Night Before” and was pleasantly surprised by how hilarious I found it. And also by the fact that JGL is basically the star of the movie. I thought it was silly and light-hearted but quite charming, and I laughed very hard of it. My favorite part, though, was JGL’s dimples. Runner-up: “The Force Awakens.” I know the entire planet was super-excited for this movie but I was mostly dreading it because I remembered how all of the prequel movies were. I was very pleasantly surprised by this movie being, like, actually good. Good dialogue! Good acting! Good job! Movie with the Best Clothing: “SPECTRE.” Everyone in this movie wears the most spectacular clothing. None of it is at all practical (good job packing a white pants suit to go take down a megalomaniac) and don’t even get me started on when the Bond girl bought that evening gown and how it got packed in her tiny bag but it was all so beautiful. If you’re not going to make any sense, at least look lovely doing it. The woman looked gorgeous, Daniel Craig looked edible, and Q’s sweater in Switzerland made me want to be best friends with Q. Can we make that happen? British Actor with the Most Amazing Hair This Year: Ben Whishaw. In a year when one of my other British boyfriends just kept saying sad things about his beautiful hair, Ben Whishaw was never afraid to let his hair grow ever more cotton-candy-ish atop his head. Own it, Ben; you wear it well. Best British Actor Moment This Year: Tom Hardy bringing Woody to the “Legend” premiere. There was genuinely a time in my life when Tom Hardy elicited merely a shrug from me, and now I see photos of him and think, Look at that gorgeous specimen of a man. Best Moment in a Movie Theater: The gun barrel opening of “SPECTRE.” I was SO NERVOUS, you guys. So nervous they wouldn’t do this. AND THEN THEY DID. Best Fiction Book: “The Lies of Locke Lamora.” This was recommended to me by someone on Twitter so I stuck it on my TBR list, and then randomly I picked it up this summer when it was the only book on my TBR list that was in the bookstore I was in. Lucky me, because I adored this book. I think I read it described somewhere as Ocean’s Eleven only on an alien planet and yup, basically. I love stories about con artists and heists and stuff anyway, and this is a really gloriously good one, and Locke is a delight of a character. Trust me: Go read this. Best Non-Fiction Book: “Walkable City.” I have long wanted to learn more about urban planning. I feel like, in a different life, where I understood engineering, I would have been an urban planner. It has long been a topic of great fascination to me. So I solicited a bunch of reading recs on Twitter and once again ended up with this one because it was the one in the bookstore I was in. But this book was AMAZING. I think of things I learned in this book all the time. I learned about how parking works, and how walking works, and how public transportation should work, and how streets should be built, and how to get rid of traffic, and seriously, I think people are sick of listening to me talk about the things I learned in this book, but I learned A LOT. And it was very readable and engaging. If you want to know more about why you sit in traffic or why you should be paying for parking, I recommend you read this book, too. Favorite Ship This Year: the couple on “Fixer-Upper.” I chose “Love It or List It” as the show in my HGTV verse, but the more I watched HGTV this year, the more I realized that my real basis for Arthur and Eames in that ‘verse was the couple on “Fixer-Upper” (funnily enough, the name I gave the first fic). These two are so sweet and adorable. I love them. Most Delightful Thing to Happen This Year: “Next Big Thing.” I never expected anything about NBT. It was not a story I planned to write. At all. I have never written a fic in such real time. I have never written a fic with such extravagant amounts of reader input. I have never written a fic so meta. That fic is *multi* meta. I mean, it’s a fic about being the object of fandom and then belonging to your own fandom. It’s a fic in which the main characters read and write fic. It’s meta-ception. And, truthfully, I’m not sure I’ve ever written such a self-indulgent fic before. I loved every second of NBT. Every second of it. It threw off everything about my writing schedule in a way I still haven’t recovered from, but I think I needed NBT. And I think I needed all of you who read it, who comment-partied every night, who shaped it with your reactions and your suggestions and your love. It’s basically a crowd-sourced fic, and it reminded me of how much fun fandom can be. And am I tickled by having the most commented-on fic on all of AO3? Well, yeah, I am, I have to admit. I consider it a marvelous treat to have had NBT this year, and I thank all of you for making it the unforgettable ride that it was. The best part about NBT to me is that AO3 still won’t let me mark it as complete. It’s basically the fic that will never end. And I somehow think that’s kind of appropriate for it.

Weirdest Television Show I Watched This Year: “London Spy.” Everyone online was watching this show, and I was worried it would start airing on BBCA while I was home in January (which isn’t good television-watching time for me) so I asked my friends if maybe they wanted to give it a try. Favorite Television Show: “Lip Sync Battle.” This show brings me more joy than anything else on television. Every time I watch it, I’m amazed that it exists. Television Moment of the Year: JGL’s “Rhythm Nation.” As soon as “Lip Sync Battle” became a thing, I was desperate for JGL to go on it. AND THEN IT FINALLY HAPPENED. AND IT WAS AMAZING. Favorite Plotted Television Show: There was a time when I thought it would be easier to pay for television a la carte, and then I could just pay for the stations I wanted and ignore all the other ones. What the rise of streaming services has actually taught me, though, is that I am apparently too lazy and unfocused to pay for television that way. Which is to say that I was bored by pretty much all conventional television this year but also lacking in the ambition to do unconventional television. So why it is “Heroes Reborn” decided to immediately launch into roughly eleventy billion different storylines and expect me to care about all of these characters I couldn’t even keep straight was beyond me. There were a couple of moments that were mildly good about this show, but mostly I just missed the inappropriate chemistry of the Petrelli family. Weren’t we all just watching for that anyway? Show That Has Fallen into the "Happy Couples Are Boring" Self-Fulfilling Prophecy: "Castle." Happy couples are *not* boring. I just spent hundreds of thousands of words with a couple that refused to be anything but happy. They're not boring. Too bad "Castle" won't let us see that. Favorite Character: Ravi from “iZombie.” Hot and smart and delightfully snarky, Ravi is actually the star of this show, I think (which is otherwise also noteworthy for Liv’s hair, which is the television hair I covet the most). Runner-up: Missy from “Doctor Who.” A lot of times, the Doctor can just take everything so seriously. I find Missy a breath of fresh air. I especially like what she brings out in the Doctor. I buy their complex, messed-up, ill-advised relationship. It’s exactly how I think the Doctor’s relationship with the Master should be at this point. I still miss John Simm’s Master, but Missy is a sparkling take on the character. Character Who Makes Me Roll My Eyes a Lot: Me on “Doctor Who.” Ugh, am I supposed to find her endearing or something? Am I supposed to think she’s some kind of moral conscience keeping the Doctor in line? Am I supposed to feel bad for her? Because mostly I can’t stand all of her judgey speechifying all the time. And I genuinely can’t tell if the show thinks I’m supposed to like her or what. Character I Am Most Tired of: Lily on “The Vampire Diaries.” I do not understand why this woman continues to wonder why her sons don’t like her. Apparently, Lily is the stupidest vampire to have ever lived for centuries. And I do not understand why the rest of her little coven is so devoted to her. For instance: “Oh, look, here’s the real love of Klaus’s life, ignore that we’ve never mentioned her before!” I love Elijah, of course, but the real reason I keep watching “The Originals” is because they keep mentioning Rebekah often enough that I live in hope of a full-time return and a glorious reunion with Marcel. Rebekah has always been one of my favorite characters. I miss her desperately. STOP TEASING ME, “ORIGINALS.” Show Most Likely to Make Me Hungry: “The Great Holiday Baking Show.” I have never seen the British original because I’ve failed at catching it on PBS when it airs, but I was on top of things enough to DVR “The Holiday Baking Show” and it was very charming and also I spent every single episode starving. Television Show That Reminded Me That I Don’t Really Remember the Book That Well: “Jonathan Strange and Mr. Norrell.” I actually really adored that book, but it has been years since I read it, and I mainly spent the television show being like, …Did that happen in the book? I don’t remember that being that way. Wait, wasn’t there something else here? Et cetera. That said, I thought this was a very good adaptation, even if I thought it didn’t quite get across how brilliantly and intricately plotted the book is. Most Fun Episode of Television This Year: “The Husbands of River Song.” I was excited for the return of River Song, because somehow, someway, River Song has become one of my favorites. It was very caper-y, very light and breezy, and the fact that it ended with that “happily ever after,” when River’s story started off as a bedtime story in her very first episode, gah, that just killed me. I need to re-watch all of River’s episodes and they probably make no sense, but there was a weird way in which I was seriously impressed at how much sense this episode managed to make to me. It reminded me of what Moffat can do.

Sherlock used music like a second language. No, like a primary language. Like the only way he could express himself. At times the music would just bubble out of him. I wrote up an incredibly long review of SPECTRE, so if you want to know specifically what I thought about SPECTRE, it is there in great detail (spoiler: I loved it). But, as I was watching the movie, I was having the thought that all franchises with long canons eventually reboot. Like, I love James Bond movies, absolutely adore them, and I love the Daniel Craig James Bond movies, but they exist in this sort of weird parallel universe place where all of the other James Bond movies both do and do not exist all at the same time, like some sort of Schrodinger's cat of canon. Like, on the one hand, everything in the Craig movies feels new, like it's happening to this Bond for the first time, like it's a straight reboot, and, on the other hand, the movies contain all these sly references to the old movies as if they also all happened, too. Like, "SPECTRE" has a little aside where Bond says he called his American friend Felix, who has not shown up yet in Craig's films, I don't think, but is a pretty steady presence in every Bond era before Craig, and I loved the little acknowledgment of history while at the same time being like, "Is there a timeline in these movies anymore? Or does everything just exist all at once?" And this is a thing I've also been thinking with regard to a show like "Doctor Who," too. I've seen a lot of criticism that "Doctor Who" has rewritten what's happened so many times that it's impossible to untangle. But that's what's happened to the Bond films as well. So it seems like it's a trend. To keep your canon going, you have to weirdly be willing to jettison a bunch of it. And this is really what's happening with "Sherlock," too. Like, "Sherlock" itself was a massive reboot of the canon: take the canon, move it to the 21st century, write it all again. And now, what is "The Abominable Bride" but a reboot of that. Back in the original Victorian era, no less, which is never going to fail to crack me up. But the trailers make clear that we're not just going back to the Victorian era, we are once again doing their meet-cute. We're redoing the origin story. We're rebooting. And this isn't limited to James Bond and Moffat. This is what "Star Wars" is doing, too. Watch the "Star Wars" trailer, and they've reduced the original "Star Wars" (by which I mean the original trilogy and not all those terrible prequels) to the stuff of myth and legend, which gives them room to stretch out in their canon, jettison a bunch of it, reboot and try again. And it's what "Star Trek" has done as well. And this all makes total sense to me, upon reflection. Because I think you reach a point where you will just drown under the weight of your own canon. Where there is too much that has already been happened, too much that has been foreclosed, and there is nowhere else to go. You feel strangled and suffocated and trapped. So you reboot. It's the only way to move ahead. This is something we should all understand, because this is the true fanfiction impulse, I think. I feel like we write ourselves a lot of fix-it fics to fic the canon, but what we're really doing, in every single fic, is rebooting. Doing it this way, and then that way, and then this way. I have written Sherlock and John meeting and falling in love countless times. I get why Mofftiss want to go back to that. It's fun. "Sherlock" and "Star Trek" are not just pieces of fanfiction in the sense that they're writing new stories about old characters. They're also pieces of fanfiction because they're doing it by rebooting. Canon gets in the way. We all feel it. I've had a hard time writing "Sherlock" after S3 because I don't know what I'm supposed to do with the canon and the advice I've usually received is, "Just ignore it." The impulse to do this in fanfiction is exactly what all of the canon creators find themselves confronting at a certain point: The canon has left them nowhere to go. So they have to just ignore it. And that upsets us as fans, frequently. Or, well, it upsets me. I have, for a long time, felt like it's cheating, somehow. Like, you made that mess, fix it. But the thing is, I'm starting to think now that's not fair. Because I actually think there is no way to not end up in a mess, the longer you draw out your canon. It's inevitably going to get there. I have the freedom to start the next AU, to move on, to write it again and have everyone understand what I'm doing because I'm writing fic and it's how we live. I think I've been judging the canon creators more harshly. Maybe because I've been internalizing the idea that they must be "better" than me because they're writing the canon and I'm just doing the fic, but no, they're exactly the same as me, they're going to hit exactly the same issues, no matter what. They're not acrobats who will escape this. Their canon will drown them, so they have to reboot. I have written multiple Sherlock AUs and multiple Inception AUs. Not because it got boring once I got them together--I hate the myth that established relationship stories are inevitably boring, because that is just not true and I love to write and read established relationship stories--but because I loved them so much that I itched to fix them again, make them happy again, be back in that moment with them where I got to do that for them. I notably didn't really do that with my Doctor Who fic, but you know what I did instead? I moved on to the next generation. I had OCs that the stories then started to revolve around, and I got to write them falling in love, or finding their adventures, getting to know their TARDISes, etc. This is why soap operas don't drown under the weight of their canon as often as all the stuff I just mentioned, because they move on to new characters. But I think, if you're going to keep the same central characters, reboots might be an inevitable part of it. They certainly seem to be in a lot of contexts. And I get that. In a weird way, watching "SPECTRE" and its weird ambiguous timeline, I was like, "I get this. You want all of the James Bonds to exist at once. Because you love them all. That's a good thing. I support that." I have always said, honestly, that I would rather my canon creators love their characters to absolute distraction and let that be the cause of their mistake, then not care about them and make mistakes out of indifference. And, as a random aside, I do not ship 00Q, but if you do, wow, is this movie a gift. I could not get over how suggestive all of Bond and Q's dialogue was. Like, the very first line said to Bond about Q is that Q has something very special in store for Bond. Was that just me reading it through your ship goggles? What about the fact that Bond's in trouble and so Q shows up where he is? Instead of, like, you know, getting in touch with him any other way? And then immediately says to him, "Come to my hotel room." I have thought recently that I love "Inception" because my canon's closed and no one's going to come in and interfere with it and that's lovely, but this movie actually made me wish that I got new canon that looked like that (instead of new canon like S3 of "Sherlock" that just destroyed me). You guys in that fandom, enjoy yourselves. I'll have a martini and toast the glee I'm sure you're experiencing.

I received the following comment on a fic: “I was totally into it until you quoted from the show.”

Fascinating, I thought. Does that mean I’ve done my job *too* well, that you forgot you were reading a fanfic? Or does that mean I haven’t done my job well enough, that you forgot you were reading a fanfic?

So then I started chatting with elizabethminkel about all of this and somehow I found myself bringing up Derrida and she was like, “You should put this all on Tumblr!” and I was like, “BEHOLD THE POWER OF PROCRASTINATION.” Seriously, the power of procrastination is such that my brain dredged up *Derrida,* who I haven’t thought about in 15 years and never actually understood.

BUT. I have always felt like, if I’ve done my job right, my fic *shouldn’t* entirely stand on its own. I intend for it to be read in conjunction with a canon. I’m doing something with the canon: commenting on it, criticizing it, hating it, loving it,  but whatever I’m doing, it’s *something.* So I have always in my head felt like the best fanfic isn’t easily serial-number-filed, if that makes sense. It should be more than changing a character name or two. Taking a fic outside of its canon conversation should, I’ve always thought, deprive it of something.

But even as I was tweeting this--which is a theory I have long held--I realized that my Inception experience was arguing against that. I started reading Inception fic kind of randomly, without knowing much about the movie at all. I fell in love with the fic. To this day, I’m kind of meh on the movie. In a kind of reverse, to me the *movie* only has value because of its place in the fan conversation. Take the movie outside of its fan conversation, and it’s deprived of full vibrancy. You don’t get fully fleshed out characters anymore. You don’t get one ridiculous word or look or musical cue or WHATEVER having so much significance your heart hurts.

So maybe I’ve been wrong to see it as a one-sided thing. It’s not that fic needs canon. It’s that fic and canon have a symbiotic relationship. Fic betters canon as much as canon betters fic. Which makes sense when I stop to think about it. The whole reason most people write fic is because there’s something about canon they can’t get out of their head, that they need *more* on, and then when you go back, everything is richer.

Which is what gets me to Derrida, I think. Derrida had something to do with referents, if I vaguely remember correctly. It was something to do with symbols not being universal because you had to know their referent? And the referent was itself a symbol and unknowable? Or something like that. As far as I could tell, modern philosophy eventually devolved into NO ONE KNOWS ANYTHING EVER. ANYWAY, I really just wanted to borrow the idea of the referent.

Because I think, what’s important in fic, is not the referent back to canon, as I’d always thought. It’s the referent to, for lack of a better word, *fanon.* And I don’t just mean fanon like John loves Tchaikovsky and Eames is a secret peer, or whatever might be the fanon of your choice. I’m using fanon to refer to “the way fans communicate.” And we, like many people, like artists everywhere, use our creativity to communicate, and it’s a language we all understand effortlessly, because we are versed in the referent. I’m terrible at understanding modern art (you should see me doing research when I have to have Eames talk about art, it’s hilarious), but that is largely, I suspect, because I never studied art, I never learned its language, I don’t know it’s referents. The other day a student told me she commutes from Philadelphia, and I was like, “*Philadelphia? How long does that take you???” and she replied, “It’s a three-hour drive,” and I still don’t know where Philadelphia is but it’s clearly not Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. She and I? We had different referents. I don’t actually speak Southern very fluently at all.

But I do speak fluent fanon. With very little effort, I know what you mean when you say “coffee shop AU,” or “hurt/comfort,” or “OT3,” or “Mary Sue,” or “genderswap,” and I don’t just mean that it’s a matter of vocabulary, it’s a matter of *we know how to read these things.* Even if I *don’t* say it’s a coffee shop AU, when there’s a coffee shop involved, you know what it *means,* you know what I’m engaging with, and it’s not just the canon, it’s hardly at all about the canon, it’s about the larger fan vocabulary that has established coffee shop AUs and what they mean. And partly there’s an illumination of the canon, but also partly it’s just another drop in the coffee shop AU referent pool, regardless of the canon at issue. Our primary referent, actually, is fandom itself; canon is the secondary referent that we use to communicate through our primary referent. ::making up philosophical-sounding things like a pro::

@elizabethminkel pointed out in our Twitter conversation that probably, for me, fanon trumps canon, and I’ve decided that’s true. You know what I’ve weirdly loved about writing in Inception that I didn’t think I would: it’s closed. No one’s going to come in and mess it all up. I don’t actually *want* my ships to be canon, because I don’t trust anyone with them but *us.* And why do I trust us? Because we’re conversing in fanon terms.

Canon is presented to us with such finality. Canon is not engaging in creative play. Canon is deadly serious. “HERE I AM AND HERE IS HOW IT GOES. DEAL WITH ME.” Canon is like the closing off of doors of possibilities until there’s only one path.

Fanon, on the other hand, is aggressively *not that.* Fanon encourages the same story to be told infinity times, basically. Fanon is an explicit acknowledgment that there is no one way to tell a story, no one way to write a character, no one ending that is inevitable, and no one gets to tell you otherwise. Fanon is about the joy of pure limitless creativity (take that, dreamsharing). Fanon is about finding your own path and letting everyone else find theirs as well. This is why you don’t only have one AU of each type in a fandom, or one definitive post-Reichenbach fic, or one fic dealing with Mary. You get multiple because no one behaves like or would ever expect anyone else to behave like their fic is THE DEFINITIVE. I can read a fic I don’t agree with and I know it’s okay for me to shrug and move on to other fics. I can read a fic I adore passionately, but it’s also okay for me to write a fic dealing with the same moment, or genre, or whatever. Whereas I am not as good at doing that when it’s canon, because I feel slightly bullied, somehow. Like, I’ve had a hard time post-S3 with Sherlock, because I can’t figure out how to deal with Mary. And I’ve spent all of this time trying to figure out and now I’ve reached this point where I’m like, “What does it *matter,* they’re just going to do what they want to do and we’ll be stuck with it.” It’s harder for me personally to brush canon away, because even though I’ve been a passionate fan creator for years now, I’ve never actually felt *invited* to that. There’s a definite hierarchy, and I’m the amusing upstart with a pat on the head and the “there, there, that’s not what *really* happened,” like it’s the bloody end of “Clue” or something.

Well, I’ll tell you what really happened: ALL THREE POSSIBLE ENDINGS. EVERYTHING ALL AT ONCE. ALL THE FANON REFERENTS EVER. Derrida. ::mic drop::

I think getting rid of Danny really helped because Twelve was much less defensive without Danny running around shouting about the army constantly.

• Although when I watched the little “Doctor’s Meditation” bit and it was all about war again, I was like, “Oh, God, please let’s not have this be all about Danny Pink or something.”

• Why is this episode called “The Magician’s Apprentice”? Is Bors going to have a bigger role in the next bit?

• I thought the opening was really well done. I wasn’t thrilled to death to open in the war, but the soldier really got me on his side, and those hand mines things were CREEPY.

• I no longer remember what we know and don’t know about Davros. There’s a possibility that that is the key to enjoying Doctor Who: making sure that you’re casual about it, that you don’t sit there making everything make sense. And maybe in some ways it’s sloppy writing but here is what years of fandom has, I think, finally taught me: Canon will eventually kill you. Not just the fanfic writer, but the writer of the original piece. You will eventually collapse under the weight of your own canon. You need the ability to keep re-starting every so often, because otherwise you reach the point where everything has been done. That’s either when you cancel the show, or when you decide to start re-writing your history. We get this impulse, we fans; this is the fanfic impulse. But it exists because with every word you write, you close off possibilities, until eventually you have no more possibilities, until eventually the only thing to do is to re-start yourself and make different choices. I think I’m okay with that. It’s the longest-running fictional television show of all time, or whatever. Of course it’s drowning in its own canon.

• All of that is to say that I loved this Davros plot. When the little boy said his name, I was like, “Ooooh,” and I thought Peter Capaldi nailed the reaction. (Of course, I was also like, “Only one person was ever named Davros in all of time and space? Really?”)

• By this time, I think the answer to “Where is the Doctor?” is EVERYWHERE, ALWAYS. God, time travel makes my head hurt.

• I like the Shadow Proclamation lady, she can stick around.

• That snake guy was super-creepy and I loved how he was a democracy, hahaha.

• I like Missy. I like the dynamic they’re working with her and the Doctor. I think it’s perfect. The Master has always basically been the other side of the Doctor’s coin, and I like how this brash, abrasive Doctor has a brash, abrasive Master to go with him, and I just really love how Missy’s like, “Dude, of course we’re BFFs, why do you think we fight all the time?” because that is just the best thing, it’s so interesting, this complex push-and-pull between them. I like them. I like that Missy is basically the Doctor without all the guilty self-reflection. Because yes, of course, we don’t want our hero randomly killing innocents like Missy does, but sometimes it’s nice to have someone on the canvas to be like, “Doctor, get a grip, we all have to do bad things sometimes, let’s move on.” And it’s also nice for the Doctor to have someone more on his own level so he can just say “gravity” and know Missy will pick it up. The explanation to the human companion would take so long. It’s nice to have the human companion in there and we need the human perspective to balance the Doctor’s alienness, but it’s also nice to have the Doctor and Missy working as a weirdly seamless team. And what’s great is how, in this episode, Missy isn’t the villain. It’s nice to have the Master on the canvas as just another character, and not necessarily the villain all the time.
• And I kind of like Missy and Clara thrown together like they were in this episode. I am all for Missy and Clara kind of going around saving the Doctor from himself. I’m okay with that. When Clara immediately was like, “We’re both going with him, her and I,” I was like, YES, the gang’s all here. And I loved when they two of them were gamboling about on the invisible planet, and Clara was clearly enjoying herself, and then when the planet became visible, Clara ran over to stand by Missy so they could stand united against the new threat together. LOVE.

• Clara/Jane Austen. I ship it.

• I like that UNIT calls in Clara, and I liked seeing Kate again. I did think it was weird that Clara was like, “Don’t call the Doctor, let’s not call the Doctor,” for as long as she was. Like, all your planes have stopped in the sky? I’m not sure that’s gossip. But I see why they needed to delay it. Although why didn’t she have him call and he didn’t pick up? That would have worked, too, I think.

• Clara has a motorcycle. That’s awesome. (Did we know that? I fail.)

• I like that Clara didn’t flinch when Missy brought up Danny.

• I desperately want to know what’s in the Doctor’s will. And I love that it got sent to Missy. Because, as the Doctor tries to explain to Clara, their relationship is so much more complex than just enmity.

• I love that there’s randomly a couple walking a dog underneath a frozen plane in a plaza sealed off by snipers and security.

• “He keeps trying to kill me. It’s sort of our texting.” Missy had all the great lines in this episode. Including the one about traps being her flirting. I seriously adore her.

• I actually thought the thing about how not everything is about sex, but maybe just friendship, was really interesting.

• Why doesn’t UNIT kill Missy when she starts killing people? I guess they think they need information from her, but, like, Clara is really the one who finds the Doctor, when you get right down to it. I guess they thought they needed Missy, but really Missy needed Clara. Which says a lot about how well Missy really knows the Doctor. She knows some things about him way better than Clara ever will, but she’s aware that Clara knows some things in a way Missy doesn’t.

• The Doctor thinks he’s going to die, so he goes to some random piece of Earth where nobody knows him. Actually, for this incarnation of the Doctor? I totally buy that. He seems much less sentimental than previous incarnations.

• The Doctor showing up playing an electric guitar might be when I decided to really, genuinely like Twelve. And I loved how Missy was like, “God, here we go again with him being an obnoxious showoff.” I also loved how Clara and Missy were kind of like, “Seriously?” during his terrible jokes.

• Clara saying, “He’s never like this,” and Missy being like, “Oh, you really are new, aren’t you?” Yeah, I actually felt like he seemed very Doctor-y during that bit, and I actually, as I said, really liked him. So I hope this Doctor sticks around. No wonder I was never so fond of him before.

• I love the ongoing idea that the Doctor has a terrible grasp of time.

• He introduced the word “dude” several centuries early. Excellent.

• Something about Missy with the Doctor reminds me of Hillary and David on “Love It or List It.” Don’t mind me.

• Okay, so, like, Clara and Missy lead Davros to where the Doctor is, which was totally predictable and in fact Clara even suggested the plane thing was a trap meant to make them call him (the only reason it made sense not to call him). Although Davros didn’t set up the trap, I guess Davros just had a tail on Missy and Clara? And then it turned out that Bors was actually a Dalek? And Bors was around even for the Doctor’s Meditation? So didn’t they know where the Doctor was all the time? Why did they need Clara and Missy if they already had a spy befriending the Doctor? I would like to think the weirdness of that detail is maybe why this episode is called “The Magician’s Apprentice” to point us to that? But probably it’s just usual DW confusing plotting.

• It occurs to me that for a Doctor who used to whine a lot about being all alone in the universe way back when, now he’s got a lot of people around who he’s known for years, like Missy and Davros. I mean, it would be nice if they were nicer people, but still, I’m glad we’ve gotten to the point where he isn’t actually as alone as he was, where there are people around who remember him, who know who he was, who can remind him of this. People around for him to send his will to.

• The main thing I don’t understand about this episode is that presumably Davros is one of those fixed points the Doctor can’t change? I mean, I feel a little bit like if it was so easy to kill Davros and get rid of Daleks and the Time War and everything else, it should have happened ages ago? I don’t know Classic Who so I don’t know if that’s been spoken about before.</lj-cut>
